column3: ACK ACK ACK ACK ACK  (I carry a patch on and off that does this, but it breaks from time to time and I get lazy and don't forward port it... and then regret it when something weird happens)\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/1c06aa98c63fff02679d446588fad06ae8cd706f for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu
ACK -- although I think it is a symptom of lacking a partial hash search ability, such as that is built into git.\n

Partial has searching requires a more expensive index than exact matching and isn't needed for any of the network protocol or basic functionality of the software. Though what we use today can support it, getting stuck with it would be unfortunate when it only saves us some space in logs.\n

Can this be implemented as a command line option to either display the full hash or an abbreviated hash please? I far prefer block hashes to be 15 characters long i.e. substr(5,15), and txs to be 10 chars long.\n
I personally don't care about the esthetics of the debug.log layout. What do others think?\n
I thought this was only recently introduced in a pull request recently. Is some kind of code fight going on here?\n
It was recently introduced, simply as a way of transitioning without breaking.  Removing it is not a problem, assuming people ACK this patchset.\n
Luke had a pullreq some time ago which introduced this abstraction, yes. I think it's overkill. Also, I want to extend it to transaction hashes too.\n
If we want to give people a choice about how long the hashes are (using a setting in bitcoin.conf), then surely this function would need to be re-introduced again, wouldn't it?\n

ACK. Just show the full thing.
And please let's not bikeshed about this. It's a debug log and those first
and foremost should be complete.
